Dear Ms. Taylor:
Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. Due to the
violations identified in the report, a written corrective action plan is required. The
corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the
following:
• How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
violation.
• Specific time frames for each violation as to when the action steps will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you desire technical assistance in addressing these issues, please feel free to contact
me. In any event, the corrective action plan is due within 15 days. Failure to submit an
acceptable corrective action plan will result in disciplinary action.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager at (616) 204 – 6992.
P.O. BOX 30650 • LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909
www.michigan.gov • (517) 335-1980

Sincerely,
Barbara A Cote, Licensing Consultant

III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code Emergency restraint
Title
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4160
Section (1) The use of emergency restraint as a lifesaving response for a
Description youth will be limited to:
(a) An emergency response to protect the youth or others from
an unanticipated or severely aggressive behavior that places the
youth or others at serious threat of violence or injury if no
immediate intervention occurs.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation There have been three unwarranted restraints at the facility.
Investigation When reviewing restraint incident reports, I read two
situations where Youth A was placed in restraints for non-
lifesaving situations and one time for Youth B.
Staff 1, who no longer is employed, was interviewed via
telephone on August 19, 2024. Staff 1 reported Youth A broke a
window and opened the door to a staff’s vehicle and was
attempting to get in the vehicle when Youth A was placed in a
restraint. Staff 1 stated he felt the safety reason for the restraint
was due to Youth A having access to get into the vehicle and not
knowing what was in the vehicle.
Staff 1 reported another time Youth A was placed in a restraint
was just after returning from the hospital due to swallowing glass
and other items. Staff 1 stated Youth A left the building, Staff 1
continued to follow Youth A but when Youth A got past the gym
Staff 1 placed Youth A into a restraint due to being concerned with
where or what Youth A was going to do. Staff 1 reported Youth A
just leaving the building after going to the hospital for self-harming
2

behavior was the safety concern as to why Youth A was placed in
the restraint.
Staff 1 was not involved in the restraint with Youth B.
Staff 2, who no longer is employed, was interviewed via
telephone on August 26, 2024. Staff 2 reported Youth A was
restrained in the parking lot after making the statement he was
going to vandalize staff vehicles. Staff 2 stated Youth A had not
actually done anything to a vehicle, just made the statement. Staff
2 reported the safety concern for the restraint was Youth A could
have stolen a vehicle if he was able to get into the vehicle.
Staff 2 described the other time he was involved in a restraint with
Youth A was to stop Youth A from fighting another youth. Staff 2
stated he could not recall placing Youth A in a restraint in the
parking lot to stop Youth A from going AWOL.
Staff 2 was not involved in the restraint with Youth B.
Youth A was interviewed face to face at a different facility by
Consultant on August 28, 2024. Youth A denied being
restrained in or near the staff parking lot. Youth A stated he
wondered about the owner of the cars in the parking lot and staff
directed him to move away from the cars and he complied. Youth
A stated he was not restrained. Youth A stated he did not have
any concerns with his stay at the facility and would like to return.
Administrator was interviewed face to face at the facility on
August 27, 2024. Administrator reported she gave approval for
Youth B to be restrained in the breakroom. Administrator stated
staff have all their personal belongings in the breakroom, which
would have included keys to staffs’ vehicles. Administrator
described Staff 3 calling from the breakroom to report Youth B had
car keys. Administrator stated she instructed Staff 3 to get the
keys and to remove Youth B from the breakroom.
Staff 3 was interviewed face to face at the facility on August
27, 2024. Staff 3 was only involved in Youth B’s restraint. Staff 3
described Youth B kicking in the door to the staffs’ breakroom,
entering the room and actively searching the lockers for keys.
Staff 3 stated Youth B would not respond to any verbal redirection
by Staff 1, Staff 2 or himself. Staff 3 reported he called
Administrator and she said to restrain Youth B. Staff 3 stated
Staff 1 and Staff 2 placed Youth B in a standing restraint. Staff 3
3

reported the safety concern was Youth B was actively searching
for keys and potentially finding keys.
Youth B was interviewed face to face at the facility on August
27, 2024. Youth B described being “bored,” so he broke into the
staffs’ breakroom. Youth B stated Staff 3 called Administrator and
Administrator said to place Youth B in a restraint. Youth B
reported Staff 1 and Staff 2 placed him in a restraint. Youth B
stated he went into the breakroom and just sat down. Youth B
denied going through lockers or trying to find car keys. Youth B
stated he did not know why he was placed in a restraint. Youth B
reported he was not injured, and the restraint was done properly.
During the investigation Youth B stated he was choked by Staff 1
or Staff 2 during a different restraint. This is being investigated in
2024SIC0001718.
Staff 4 was interviewed face to face at the facility on August
27, 2024. Staff 4 stated he could not recall a restraint with Youth
B in the breakroom. Staff 4 reported the only time staff can
restrain a youth is if the youth is being unsafe or a danger to
themselves or others. Staff 4 stated there are many restraints at
the facility, so it is difficult to recall all of them.
Staff 5 was interviewed face to face at the facility on August
27, 2024. Staff 5 reported there was not a restraint with Youth B
in the breakroom, that the restraint occurred outside of the facility.
Staff 5 reported Youth B broke into the breakroom and stood in
the middle of the room but eventually walked out on his own
accord.
Video Reviewed:
There are no cameras in the breakroom. Video does not cover
the area outside the gym or in the parking lot where the restraints
occurred with Youth A.
Documents Reviewed:
• Incident Report 191370238 for Youth A. Incident report
documents, Youth A returned from the hospital and walked
in the door and then immediately turned around and walked
out the door. Youth A passed the parking lot side of the
gym, staff initiated a small child hold.
• Incident Report 191360239 for Youth A. Incident report
documents, Youth A reached the staff parking lot, he was
upset, and asked which vehicle was staffs. To prevent
damage to vehicles, Youth A was placed into a CPI Low
Standing Restraint and walked back to site.
4

• Incident Report 191560238 for Youth B. Incident report
documents, Youth B got into the building, he broke into the
breakroom and started to go through staff's lockers. Staff
placed Youth B in a Standing Restraint and escorted him
out of the breakroom.
• Staff 1’s personnel file: There was no disciplinary record
and Staff 1 completed the required Crisis Prevention
Institute (CPI) on 2/12/24.
• Staff 2’s personnel file: Staff 2 had one write up not related
to restraints. Staff 2 completed the required CPI on
2/28/24.
• Staff 3’s personnel file: Staff 3 had one write up not related
to restraints. Staff 3 completed the required CPI on
2/12/24.
• Staff 4’s personnel file: Staff 4 had three write ups not
related to restraints. Staff 4 completed the required CPI on
2/12/24.
• Staff 5’s personnel file: There was no disciplinary record
and Staff 5 completed the required CPI on 2/12/24.
• Behavior Support and Management Policy: Policy
documents restrictive intervention is used when a youths’
behavior would result in physical injury or imminent risk of
physical harm of the client, other client, staff members, or
others.
Analysis The agency is found in non-compliance as per staff and youth
interviews, staff restrained Youth A and Youth B for non-lifesaving
situations.
Conclusion Repeat Violation Established
2024SIC0001251 dated 5/09/2024, CAP Approved 7/01/2024
SIR2023C0000600 dated 8/29/2023, CAP Approved 9/20/2023
5

IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it
is recommended that the current license status be continued.
